title: Definitions
context: §521-8 Definitions. As used in this chapter, unless the context clearly requires otherwise: &ldquo;Action&rdquo; with reference to a judicial proceeding includes recoupment, counterclaim, setoff, and any other proceedings in which rights are determined, including an action for possession. &ldquo;Apartment building&rdquo; means a structure containing one or more dwelling units, except: (1) A single-family residence, or (2) A structure in which all tenants are roomers or boarders. &ldquo;Dwelling unit&rdquo; means a structure, or part of a structure, which is used as a home, residence, or sleeping place by one person or by two or more persons maintaining a common household, to the exclusion of all others. &ldquo;Landlord&rdquo; means the owner, lessor, sublessor, assigns or successors in interest of the dwelling unit or the building of which it is a part and in addition means any agent of the landlord. &ldquo;Normal wear and tear&rdquo; means deterioration or depreciation in value by ordinary and reasonable use but does not include items that are missing from the dwelling unit. &ldquo;Owner&rdquo; means one or more persons, jointly or severally, in whom is vested: (1) All or any part of the legal title to property; or (2) All or any part of the beneficial ownership and a right to present use and enjoyment of the property; and includes a mortgagee in possession. &ldquo;Person&rdquo; includes an individual, corporation, government or governmental agency, business trust, estate, trust, partnership or association, two or more persons having a joint or common interest, or any other legal or commercial entity. &ldquo;Premises&rdquo; means a dwelling unit, appurtenances thereto, grounds, and facilities held out for the use of tenants generally and any other area or facility whose use is promised to the tenant. &ldquo;Rental agreement&rdquo; means all agreements, written or oral, which establish or modify the terms, conditions, rules, regulations, or any other provisions concerning the use and occupancy of a dwelling unit and premises. &ldquo;Roomer&rdquo; or &ldquo;boarder&rdquo; means a tenant occupying a dwelling unit: (1) Which lacks at least one major bathroom or kitchen facility, such as a toilet, refrigerator, or stove, (2) In a building where one or more such major facilities are supplied to be used in common by the occupants of the tenant&rsquo;s dwelling unit and by the occupants of one or more other dwelling units, and (3) In a building in which the landlord resides. &ldquo;Single family residence&rdquo; means a structure maintained and used as a single dwelling unit. Notwithstanding that a dwelling unit shares one or more walls with another dwelling unit, it shall be deemed a single family residence if it has direct access to a street or thoroughfare and does not share hot water equipment or any other essential facility or service with any other dwelling unit. &ldquo;Tenant&rdquo; means any person who occupies a dwelling unit for dwelling purposes under a rental agreement. &ldquo;Utility service&rdquo; means service for electricity, water, sewer, and natural gas. [L 1972, c 132, pt of §1; am L 1975, c 10, §1; am L 1988, c 307, §2; am L 1991, c 212, §9; am L 2015, c 29, §2] Case Notes While defendant was &ldquo;a tenant&rdquo; as defined by this Code, defendant&rsquo;s tenancy was not as a sublessee, but as a licensee of defendant&rsquo;s roommate, where defendant did not have exclusive possession of the property, the unilateral right to assign defendant&rsquo;s interest in the property, and defendant&rsquo;s agreement was not for a fixed term; thus, as the holder of a license revocable at will, defendant became a trespasser when the licensor roommate&rsquo;s interest in the property ceased. 109 H. 296, 126 P.3d 339.
